rules.example: „E-Mail/e-Mail“ – beide Formen sind gleichwertig, unabhängig von der Reihenfolge.

rules.name: Priorisierung von Schreibvarianten
rules.description: Wo dieser Leitfaden sich von zwei möglichen Schreibungen für eine entschieden hat, steht im Wörterverzeichnis lediglich die priorisierte Variante.
rules.example: „E-Mail“ ist die priorisierte Schreibweise, „e-Mail“ ist nicht verzeichnet.

rules.name: Verweise auf Regeldarstellung
rules.description: In eckigen Klammern stehen Verweise auf die Randziffern der Regeldarstellung im 2. Kapitel dieses Leitfadens.
rules.example: „[2.1]“ – Verweis auf die Regel für Schrägstrich-Schreibweisen im 2. Kapitel.

rules.name: Betonungsmarkierung
rules.description: Mit der Unterstreichung von Vokalbuchstaben werden gelegentlich Betonungen markiert.
rules.example: „Beispiel“ – das unterstrichene „e“ zeigt die Betonung an.

rules.name: Capitalization of 'rot' in proper nouns
rules.description: When 'rot' is part of a proper noun or specific term, it is capitalized (e.g., 'Rote Kreuz', 'Rote Meer', 'Rote Planet'). However, in common contexts, it remains lowercase (e.g., 'rote Karte').
rules.example: die Ampel schaltete auf Rot [4.21]; das Rote Kreuz, das Rote Meer, der Rote Planet (Mars) [4.32], aber: die rote Karte [4.40]

rules.name: Hyphenation in compound adjectives
rules.description: Compound adjectives formed with 'rot' are written with a hyphen when they describe a noun (e.g., 'rot-grünes Bündnis'), but without a hyphen in other contexts (e.g., 'Rot-Grün gewinnt').

rules.name: Correct spelling of 'rotglühend'
rules.description: The compound adjective 'rotglühend' is written as one word, not as two separate words ('rot glühend').

rules.name: Avoid using 'rotsehen'
rules.description: The incorrect form 'rotsehen' (meaning 'to become angry') should be replaced with the phrase 'wütend werden'.

rules.name: Capitalization of compound nouns
rules.description: Compound nouns like 'Safer Sex' are written with both words capitalized when referring to a specific concept or proper noun.

rules.name: Correct form of 'Schande'
rules.description: The noun 'Schande' requires specific prepositions and forms (e.g., 'zu Schanden gehen', 'zuschanden machen').
rules.example: Schande, die; zu Schanden / zuschanden gehen, machen, werden, reiten [2.35]

rules.name: Hyphenation in 'Sauregurkenzeit'
rules.description: The compound noun 'Sauregurkenzeit' can be written as one word or with hyphens and capitalization when emphasizing the compound structure (e.g., 'Saure-Gurken-Zeit').

rules.name: Compound Adjective Formation for 'schutzgeimpft'
rules.description: The term 'schutzimpfen' is written as a compound adjective in the past participle form 'schutzgeimpft' when used in a sentence. Example: 'die Kinder wurden schutzgeimpft'.

rules.name: Correct Form for 'schutzsuchend' vs. 'Schutz suchend'
rules.description: The term can be written as 'schutzsuchend' (compound adjective) or 'Schutz suchend' (noun + verb). However, in the context 'Schutz in einer Kirche suchend', the noun form is preferred. Example: 'Schutz suchend'.

rules.name: Correct Form for 'schutzwürdig'
rules.description: The term 'schutzwürdig' is written as a compound adjective. Example: 'schutzwürdig'.

rules.name: Correct Form for 'schwachbegabt' vs. 'schwach begabt'
rules.description: The term can be written as 'schwachbegabt' (compound adjective) or 'schwach begabt' (adverb + adjective). Example: 'schwachbegabt'.

rules.name: Correct Form for 'schwachbevölkert' vs. 'schwach bevölkert'
rules.description: The term can be written as 'schwachbevölkert' (compound adjective) or 'schwach bevölkert' (adverb + adjective). Example: 'schwachbevölkert'.

rules.name: Correct Form for 'schwachmachen' vs. 'schwach machen'
rules.description: The term can be written as 'schwachmachen' (compound verb) or 'schwach machen' (adjective + verb). Example: 'was den Körper schwachmacht'.

rules.name: Correct Form for 'schwachwerden' vs. 'schwach werden'
rules.description: The term can be written as 'schwachwerden' (compound verb) or 'schwach werden' (adjective + verb). Example: 'sie hat alles unternommen, damit ich schwachwerde'.

rules.name: Compound Words (zusammengesetzte Substantive)
rules.description: Compound verbs should be written as one word (zusammengesetzt) in certain contexts, e.g., 'warmmachen' instead of 'warm machen'.

rules.name: Hyphenation in Compound Nouns
rules.description: Hyphenation is required in compound nouns when combining English elements with German, e.g., 'Weekend-Ausflug' with a hyphen.

rules.name: Genitive with Prepositions

rules.name: Compound Verbs with Separation
rules.description: Some compound verbs are written as two words in specific contexts, e.g., 'weich klopfen' instead of 'weichklopfen' when used as a separable verb.
rules.example: ein Stück Fleisch weichklopfen / weich klopfen [2.20, 2.16]

rules.name: Adjectives with Capitalization
rules.description: Adjectives following a noun are written with a lowercase first letter when not part of a proper noun, e.g., 'hartes Wasser, leichtes Wasser'.
rules.example: hartes Wasser, leichtes Wasser, schweres Wasser, weiches Wasser

rules.name: Proper Nouns and Acronyms
rules.description: Acronyms like 'WEF' should be written in uppercase and followed by their full form in parentheses, e.g., 'WEF, das; Kürzel f. World Economic Forum'.
rules.example: WEF, das; Kürzel f. World Economic Forum [6.7]

rules.name: Compound Adjectives with Hyphenation
rules.description: Compound adjectives in color descriptions require a hyphen, e.g., 'schwarz-weiss malen' instead of 'schwarz Weiss'.

rules.name: Separable Prefixes in Verbs
rules.description: Verbs with separable prefixes split in main clause constructions, e.g., 'weiterfahren' as 'können wir weiterfahren'.

rules.name: Compound Nouns with Capitalization
rules.description: Compound nouns are written as single words with capitalization for proper nouns, e.g., 'das Weisse Haus' instead of 'das weisse Haus'.
rules.example: das Weisse Haus, der Weisse Sonntag [4.41]

rules.name: Adverbial Phrases with '-weise'
